oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery On The Record with George Jones - Part 1
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of George Jones (performer) for Ralph Emery: On the Record With George Jones. Recording is performed in front of a live audience. Recording is from February 21, 1996. Tape is labeled part 1.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; George Jones
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Randy Travis (unconfirmed) inducts George Jones into the Country Music Hall of Fame, and Jones expresses his gratitude to country music -- (02:52) Ralph Emery expresses the accolades Jones had culminated throughout his career while introducing Jones -- (03:45) Emery inquires about the feelings Jones had the night he was inducted to the Country Music Hall of Fame; additionally, Emery and Jones introduce Jones' book: I Lived to Tell it All -- (08:18) Emery inquires to the stability of Jones' sobriety -- (10:07) Emery inquires about Jones' childhood and Jones' father's alcoholism -- (16:45) Emery asks Jones to recall how his father bought him his first guitar -- (17:58) Emery asks Jones to reflect on a picture displaying Jones in his pre-teens, and how Jones would sing on the streets -- (21:25) Emery inquires about Jones' ability to see the monitor (not live) -- (22:54) Emery asks Jones to reflect how he would sleep in his parents bed to listen to the Grand Ole Opry; additionally, Jones' nickname is discussed -- (24:26) Emery inquires as to Jones' relationship to Eddy Stevens and Pearl Stevens -- (26:55) Jones is asked to reflect on how he met Hank Williams -- (28:42) Emery inquires as to what advice Jones received from Williams, and Emery asks about the difficulties Jones had trying to sing like Williams -- (31:30) Emery jokes about what Larry Gatlin said about Jones, and Emery inquires about how Jones' met Dorothy Bonvillon -- (33:55) Emery inquires about the time where Jones was in debt and joined Marine Corps -- (39:26) Emery invites Jones to discuss the time where he left the Marine Corps and became a disc jockey -- (41:43) Emery invites Jones to reflect on the influence of Pappy Daily and Jack Starnes on Jones' recording career -- (44:58) Emery expresses his enjoyment of "Ragged But Right" -- (45:36) Emery expresses how Jones used to give Emery flak for playing Jim Reeves records, and Emery pokes fun of Thumper Jones -- (46:46) Rock It [excerpt] (Thumper Jones) -- (47:00) Emery and Jones joke about how Jones wrote "Rock It" and "How Come It" -- (48:48) Emery introduces Jones' second marriage, and how his wife did not like to have Jones play in public -- (49:57) Emery inquires about when Jones began to start drinking -- (53:53) Emery and Jones discuss how Jones' success landed him a spot on the Louisiana Hayride -- (56:31) Emery inquires about Jones' relationship to Elvis Presley -- (57:35) Emery invites Jones to discuss his time on the Grand Ole Opry, and Jones is asked to reflect on the difficulty getting on the Grand Ole Opry -- (1:00:20) Emery presents a picture in an attempt to reflect on the discord of the Grand Ole Opry -- (1:00:51) Emery asks Jones to reflect on recording "White Lightning" for Mercury Records; additionally, both joke about how Jones' alcoholism affected his recording -- (1:04:23) Jones and Emery reflect on Little George Riddle, and how Jones disliked Buck Owens' look
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Jones, George; Jones, George, 1931-2013; Emery, Ralph;
